that's basic Tunisian couscous mate :/ my mom made the exact same dish 3

top_comment.author: asha bolton

comments.text:
Il couscous si fa pure nella Sardegna sud occidentale( Carloforte,Calasetta 
etc..)
comments.author: Cristina Littarru

comments.text:
I think it can happily be the way they do it both in Sicily and in Tunisia, 
which happen to be pretty close to each other, without having to belong to 
either... :) I suppose the lovely granny of the video testify it being a 
traditional dish in Sicily, too :) nice preparation! It reminded me of my 
own grandma's cuscus, who was Sicilian but lived a fair bit of her 
childhood in Tunisia ;)
comments.author: Antonio De Sarlo

comments.text:
Muslim Arabs conquered Sicily in 827 AD and they stayed here until 1061 AD. 
For this particular reason there's a great influence of Arabic culture in 
Sicily.
comments.author: fairylizzie

comments.text: Sorry, that's traditional trapanese cuscus. Fish only.
comments.author: Alice Twain

comments.text:
I know they have Couscous in Italy but the recipe is the exact same one my 
Mother and my Grandmother uses it even looks the same, the biggest 
similarity would be the red tomato sauce that's the signature thing about 
Tunisian style couscous (By the way Couscous was introduced to Italy during 
the Punic/Roman era when Rome ruled over a large part of North Africa 
because Couscous is not an Arabic food it's Berber) It's nice to see that 
the food of my ancestors is celebrated in such way though thank you for 
that link ^^
comments.author: asha bolton

comments.text:
Actually not. Cuscus ("cuscussù" or "frascatuli" in the Marsala area) is a 
very traditional recipe of western Sicily, while in Sardinia che same 
technique is used to make fregula, a kind of extremely coarse cuscus 
(except in the Carloforte area where the traditional recuipe is "cus cus 
tabarkino" or "caskhà"). Indeed Sicily, and in particular the town of San 
Vito lo Capo, also hosts yearly "Cus cus fest", a world-wide "sagra"-tipe 
festivity with cooks from throughout the world, during which the best cus 
cus cook is selected. http://www.couscousfest.it/ (The website is available 
in several languages.) Obviously, though, for the presence of cuscus in 
Italy we must be thankful for the Arabs that ruled southern Italy in the 
Middle age!
comments.author: Alice Twain

captions.text: When I turned 30
I toured around Italy in my campervan, cooking everywhere I went
I did some amazing things which changed my life forever
and I'll never forget it.
The island of Marettimo
Couscous. This was mad, I was in a little fishing village that I had heard about
and before I knew it, this bloke took me into his mums house and I was cooking in the street enjoying it
I cant believe like, you can literally ask a bunch of people
They said oh just go and ask them, they'll let you in and they'll probably cook it with you if you want.
Oh my god, ok. si, si, capito
she's actually making the couscous, I thought she was gonna get a packet out.
I always knew that semolina made couscous
but I've never ever made it home-made
I bet you think I'm mad. What's the fuss all about! You can just buy couscous in the supermarkets, ready to go

but making it from its raw ingredient,
semolina, was something I'd never seen before

and the geek inside me needed to know
how it was done.
Si, si, si!
Very simple, you add the water to the semolina and you keep moving it
It's gone from being wet, to sort of a bit like chewy now.
I guess as far as semolina is concerned, you can't get much coarser than that.
Finito? Si.
I'm really proud of myself there. Ok so she basically said it needs condiments. Olive oil, garlic, parsley, salt to go with it.
and then it's ready to cook
So peel the onions, mummas watching. Into quarters...
Mummas telling me. She knows, she knows. Little English boy.
This, this is like my heaven actually, I've always wanted to learn how to make couscous

which we always buy. You know the
fact that she bought semolina she's made it by hand.
You know, the fact that these little granules are not like factory uniform sizes.
There sort of odd sizes...Is absolutely fantastic.
Little bit of pepper
She wants me to put this in, raw garlic, raw onion and the mashed up parsley
So that's interesting... Mix it all up
7 tablespoons of olive oil, wow!
Buono, Buono
Oh wow, The steam will come up here, into here
and very gently steam the couscous
and it's quite thick as well, so it's going to be quite a gentle steam
One hour. One hour? Wow.
Like when I've done couscous before it's been like 20 minutes, half an hour.
One hour, slowly, slowly. Everyone's got time here. Slowly.
So I'm putting the couscous into this bowl now, of course you could do it in a fine colander
Ahh...
You get a little hat wet, and then hang it over there.
and then that'll keep it nice and damp
Flour and water or semolina water and you just put it together so you've got play doe
I haven't even tasted this yet, but I know for a fact this is going to taste fantastic, because I can smell it

when it was all mixed up we needed to
cook it, but you can never be in a rush to eat in Italy.
Look in there, look.
Look at that man
Fantastic!
Grazie
Prego
Fantastico
No problemo
Buono, molto, molto buono
Fantastic. It's light, it's really pungent.
Ciao, Ciao
So guys, subscribe now, it's free and if you like this please like it
and if you want to comment, please comment
and of course, share it on Facebook and Twitter and all that stuff
Lot's of love guys, thanks ever so much and enjoy!

title: Authentic Italian Couscous | Jamie’s Italy - UNSEEN
